references: Should an ill-posed partition appear while no alternative way exists to decompose the domain, the space cannot be triangulated. Unfortunately, ill-posed partitions suggest that poloidal discretization is insufficient. In this case, one can refine the poloidal resolution with a smaller gap Δ⁢ϕΔitalic-ϕ\Delta\phiroman_Δ italic_ϕ so that no ill-posed partitions appear.111In general, the distortion decreases with a finer poloidal resolution Δ⁢ϕΔitalic-ϕ\Delta\phiroman_Δ italic_ϕ; the distortion characterized by displacement ‖Φ⁢(𝐩,ϕ0,ϕ)−𝐩‖normΦ𝐩subscriptitalic-ϕ0italic-ϕ𝐩||\Phi(\mathbf{p},\phi_{0},\phi)-\mathbf{p}||| | roman_Φ ( bold_p , italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ ) - bold_p | | is bounded by L⋅Δ⁢ϕ⋅𝐿Δitalic-ϕL\cdot\Delta\phiitalic_L ⋅ roman_Δ italic_ϕ, L𝐿Litalic_L being the Lipschitz constant of 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B. In other words, one can upsample the toroidal resolution with field-following interpolation (Eq. (2)) before space meshing.

Evaluation scheme. We define and use two types of approximations: forward approximation, i.e., interpolation of function values f𝑓fitalic_f at given 3D locations, such as volume rendering and particle tracing, which require sampling at arbitrary locations for ray/path integration, and inverse approximation, i.e., root-finding of 3D locations with given function values, including isosurfacing in scalar-valued functions and critical-point-finding in vector-valued functions. We compare three types of interpolation schemes: (i) magnetic-following interpolation defined in Eq. (2) that requires magnetic-line tracing, (ii) piecewise linear interpolation based on our simplicial meshing scheme that models deforming space, and (iii) a naive baseline based on simplicial meshing on uniform space where every node’s next node is itself. The three interpolation schemes are measured by mean squared error (MSE), peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), and running time. Compared with magnetic-following interpolation, our method significantly reduces the computational cost of all visualization tasks, because no magnetic-line tracing is involved for the interpolation. We recognize that the piecewise linear (PL) approximation introduces error, and thus we treat the magnetic-following interpolation as the ground truth and quantitatively evaluate the error resulting from our method. We also work together with domain scientists to evaluate our results qualitatively.

For W7-X, we aggregate the number of nodes, triangles, and timings for 256 pairs of adjacent poloidal planes. references: We compare our method with TetGen [18], a general-purpose tool for generating tetrahedral meshes from a 3D input domain, with results shown in Table 1. The difference in purpose and algorithm between our method and TetGen is discussed in Section 5. TetGen only accepts constraints defined by cycles (e.g., triangles), so we specify the next node connectivity constraints between adjacent meshes using the cycles formed by pairs of cutting edges (Section 3.1). Our method generates 339,626 tetrahedra with 56,980×2=113,960formulae-sequence56980211396056,980\times 2=113,96056 , 980 × 2 = 113 , 960 nodes for ITER data, and 1,117,41911174191,117,4191 , 117 , 419 to 1,121,07411210741,121,0741 , 121 , 074 tetrahedra with 187,561×2=375,122formulae-sequence1875612375122187,561\times 2=375,122187 , 561 × 2 = 375 , 122 nodes for every two adjacent poloidal planes in W7-X. TetGen is unable to generate a valid tetrahedralization that satisfies the constraints imposed by the two input meshes and the next-node connectivity for ITER and W7-X data. To enable a fair comparison, we generate synthetic data, with details provided in the Supplementary Materials. Across all datasets, our method is at least 10 times faster than TetGen. Notably, our approach avoids the introduction of unnecessary Steiner points, which reduces the time required to compute scalar values at these points through magnetic line-following interpolation.

references: Toroidal Upsampling (Forward Approximation). The objective of the toroidal upsampling case study is to upsample ITER’s 3D scalar field data, which are simulated with relatively low resolution (e.g., nϕ=16subscript𝑛italic-ϕ16n_{\phi}=16italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 16) uniformly along the toroidal direction at ϕ=2⁢π⁢i/16italic-ϕ2𝜋𝑖16\phi=2\pi i/16italic_ϕ = 2 italic_π italic_i / 16 (i=0,1,…,15𝑖01…15i=0,1,...,15italic_i = 0 , 1 , … , 15). With each given ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, science variables (e.g., density and temperature) are given at nodes on 2D triangular meshes. We interpolate simulation outputs to obtain values of nodes at two arbitrary ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ’s, (5/32)⁢2⁢π5322𝜋(5/32)2\pi( 5 / 32 ) 2 italic_π and (27/32)⁢2⁢π27322𝜋(27/32)2\pi( 27 / 32 ) 2 italic_π, which are both in the middle of two consecutive poloidal planes, to retrieve a much higher toroidal resolution of the data by the three interpolation methods. Results of the three methods and quantitative evaluation are shown in Figure 10 and Table 2, respectively. Our method shows a similar pattern of values, low MSE and high PSNR, and significantly less running time (O⁢(104)𝑂superscript104O(10^{4})italic_O ( 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) faster) when compared with magnetic-following interpolation. See how the running time varies over ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ in Supplemental Materials.
